summary: This is a grand jury subpoena issued by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, commanding an unnamed recipient to appear before the grand jury on August 20, 2019, and produce all materials relating to Jeffrey Epstein. The subpoena includes an attached rider detailing the recipient's rights and the scope of required document production.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Issued and signed the grand jury subpoena dated August 15, 2019, commanding an individual to appear and produce documents related to Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subpoena demands the production of all materials relating to him, indicating he is the central subject of the grand jury investigation.

connections.description: Berman, as U.S. Attorney, is issuing a subpoena to gather evidence for a grand jury investigation into Epstein.

events.title: Grand Jury Appearance
events.description: The unnamed recipient of the subpoena is commanded to appear before the Grand Jury for the Southern District of New York to testify and give evidence.

events.title: Subpoena Issued
events.description: The grand jury subpoena is dated and issued by U.S. Attorney Geoffrey S. Berman.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, Room 220, Borough of Manhattan, City of New York, New York, Southern District of New York
One St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: A grand jury subpoena was issued on August 15, 2019, for an individual to appear on August 20, 2019, and produce all materials related to Jeffrey Epstein.
The subpoena demands production of all communications and documents, including text messages, emails, and social media messages, relating to Jeffrey Epstein.
The investigation involves alleged violations of federal statutes 18 U.S.C. §§ 371 (conspiracy), 1001 (false statements), and 1519 (destruction, alteration, or falsification of records).
The recipient is advised of their rights, including the right against self-incrimination and the right to counsel.
The subpoena's scope is extensive, covering electronically stored material on devices and accounts, whether located in the U.S. or any foreign jurisdiction.
